The NMC Competency Framework
The NMC Standards for pre-registration nursing education (2010) set out the standards for
competence and the related competencies that every nursing student must acquire before
applying to be registered at first level on the nurses’ part of the register. The assessment of
practice requirements set out in this document reflects the field specific and generic
competencies set out in the NMC Standards for pre-registration nursing education (2010).
The full version of the NMC generic and field specific competencies can be accessed via the
DVD in the Placement Support Resource Pack which accompanies this assessment of
practice document and these can also be viewed via the DPL web site.
The generic standards for competence focus on four domains and are reproduced below as
they appear in the NMC Standards.
Domain 1: Professional Values
All nurses must act first and foremost to care for and safeguard the public. They must
practise autonomously and be responsible and accountable for safe, compassionate,
person-centred, evidence-based nursing that respects and maintains dignity and human

instruction: Explain the domains of the NMC Competency Framework.
output:
practise autonomously and be responsible and accountable for safe, compassionate,
person-centred, evidence-based nursing that respects and maintains dignity and human
rights. They must show professionalism and integrity and work within recognised
professional, ethical and legal frameworks. They must work in partnership with other health
and social care professionals and agencies, service users, their carers and families in all
settings, including the community, ensuring that decisions about care are shared.
Domain 2: Communication and interpersonal skills
All nurses must use excellent communication and interpersonal skills. Their communications
must always be safe, effective, compassionate and respectful. They must communicate
effectively using a wide range of strategies and interventions including the effective use of
communication technologies. Where people have a disability, nurses must be able to work
with service users and others to obtain the information needed to make reasonable
adjustments that promote optimum health and enable equal access to services.
Domain 3: Nursing practice and decision-making

output:

Domain 3: Nursing practice and decision-making
All nurses must practise autonomously, compassionately, skilfully and safely, and must
maintain dignity and promote health and wellbeing. They must assess and meet the full
range of essential physical and mental health needs of people of all ages who come into
their care. Where necessary they must be able to provide safe and effective immediate care
to all people prior to accessing or referring to specialist services irrespective of their field of
practice. All nurses must also meet more complex and coexisting needs for people in their
own nursing field of practice, in any setting including hospital, community and at home. All
practice should be informed by the best available evidence and comply with local and
national guidelines. Decision-making must be shared with service users, carers and families
and informed by critical analysis of a full range of possible interventions, including the use of
up-to-date technology. All nurses must also understand how behaviour, culture,

instruction: Explain the domains of the NMC Competency Framework.
output:
and informed by critical analysis of a full range of possible interventions, including the use of
up-to-date technology. All nurses must also understand how behaviour, culture,
socioeconomic and other factors, in the care environment and its location, can affect health,
illness, health outcomes and public health priorities and take this into account in planning
and delivering care.
Domain 4: Leadership, management and team working
All nurses must be professionally accountable and use clinical governance processes to
maintain and improve nursing practice and standards of healthcare. They must be able to
respond autonomously and confidently to planned and uncertain situations, managing
themselves and others effectively. They must create and maximise opportunities to improve
services. They must also demonstrate the potential to develop further management and
leadership skills during their period of preceptorship and beyond.

Learning Disability/Mental Health First Year 1: Medicines Management
This assessment must be completed in First Year where the student safely administers medicines to a group of patients/service users or a caseload of patients/service users in any care settings.
During First year the student should be developing their knowledge and skills in relation to the safe administration of medicines. This assessment should normally be undertaken with one or more patients/service users.
The student must be allowed a number of practice opportunities to administer medicines under supervision prior to this assessment.
The student must work within the legal and ethical frameworks that underpin safe and effective medicines management and work within national and local policies.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
How can student be encouraged more to take responsibility for and direct their own learning?
Learning opportunities should be individualised to the student’s learning needs, their position within their programme, their learning outcomes, and any student needs including reasonable adjustments.
Students should also be given the opportunity to direct their own learning where possible, guiding their learning and identifying what is needed. When students are given these opportunities, the AEI with its practice learning partners, must take into account various risks to ensure the safety of people. This includes the student’s level of skill and competence, the activity, and the environment in which it is taking place.
Feedback and handover are also important aspects of a learning experience. Students must be given opportunities to challenge and improve their own practice and behaviour.
Student also have a responsibility to take advantage of multiple learning opportunities within and across environments, in order to work towards becoming a safe and independent practitioner. They should be empowered to do so by the AEI and their practice learning partners

Utilising spoke opportunities during placement periods can be a very effective way of enhancing learning experiences. This being with regards gaining increased knowledge and exposure to a patient journey and the context of local service delivery and provision.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.

Utilising spoke placements can also support the development of knowledge and skills in relation to proficiencies. This being specifically with regards to proficiencies that may be difficult to achieve due to the opportunities of exposure, within the learners allocated placement area.
For example, a learner placed within a nurse-led clinic, may not have the opportunity to gain exposure to proficiencies regarding end-of-life care. So a spoke within a bereavement team or with a palliative care specialist nurse, would support learning and development.
Spoke placements can be useful to if there is limited exposure to a proficiency in a specific field of nursing. For example; a .or . nursing student may arrange an “out of field” spoke placement to gain access to and participate in the care for a patient requiring urethral catheterisation (under direction supervision) if exposure is limited in their current practice learning environment.

Accountability/Signing of PAD If a learner has or can provide evidence to the Practice Supervisors and/or Practice Assessor that, at that time, confirms to them the learning has been achieved and they document this in the relevant documentation (PAD) then there is clear evidence base for the decision of the Practice Assessor. instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Assessment responsibilities Each practice assessor is responsible for the assessment and confirmation of the achievement of proficiencies and programmes outcomes in practice learning for the student(s) they are assigned to, for the period they are assigned to them. A good assessment is evidenced based, objective and fair, taking into account a variety of views and inputs, and student diversity, such as different learning styles, cultural backgrounds and communication styles. The practice assessor should take into account the student’s history of achievement and their achievement across theory and practice. Assessment should be continuous throughout the time in which a practice assessor is assigned to a student. The practice assessor should be up to date on the progress of the student they are assigned to; collation of information on a student’s performance should be managed in a way that enables this. Feedback to the student about their achievement and collaborating with them to review possible areas for improvement also forms a fundamental part of the assessment process. We do this via the PAD/OAR.

When contributing to the recommendation for progression practice assessors should take into account the student’s achievement over the whole period for which they are making the decision, e.g. a placement or a year. They should also consider the student’s achievement in previous parts of the programme (if any) and how they have progressed over the programme.
Once they have assessed the student’s practice learning for the placement(s) they are assigned to the student, they should ensure that there is a proper handover to the next practice assessor, and any other relevant people involved in the education of the student. This includes ensuring that all relevant documentation is up to date, and any particular issues with the student’s performance have been recorded or communicated with the next practice assessor and all relevant people.

Practice Assessment Documents (PAD)
These documents are the online document that PS/PAs complete to inform the AEIs the student has met the required outcomes in practice. The PAD must be completed accurately and in a timely manner to enable to student’s assessment to be processed in the AEI and allow the student to progress or be re-assessed (see below) if necessary.
Formative

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
Summative
Formal assessments that have clear outcomes to be met within a timeframe e.g., assessment document outcomes by the end of practice experience or the Part of the programme. The results of summative assessments are usually significant and are used to determine whether a student progresses on programme or not. It is the responsibility of the PA and student to ensure that these are fully completed in practice.
Retrieval/Re-assessment
‘Reassessment’ or ‘Retrieval’ is the wording used when a student has not achieved the outcome(s) required and therefore requires a further attempt in practice to achieve those outcomes. The AA and PA can agree an appropriate timeframe for achievement in this period but should be a maximum of 4 weeks. Students do not necessarily need a 4-week period for assessment of an element of the assessment document e.g., if they just have an Episode of Care to complete, that doesn’t need 4 weeks to complete.
Simulation

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
Simulation
An artificial representation of a real-world practice scenario that supports student development through experiential learning with the opportunity for repetition, feedback, evaluation and reflection. Effective simulation facilitates safety by enhancing knowledge, behaviours and skills. Simulation can be undertaken in any environment and can be through scenarios, role play etc.
Supernumerary

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
Supernumerary
Students in practice or work placed learning must be supported to learn without being counted as part of the staffing required for safe and effective care in that setting. For apprentices, this includes practice placements within their place of employment; this does not apply when they are working in their substantive role. Placements should enable students to learn to provide safe and effective care, not merely to observe; students can and should add real value to care. The contribution students make will increase over time as they gain proficiency, and they will continue to benefit from ongoing guidance and feedback. Once a student has demonstrated that they are proficient, they should be able to fulfil tasks without direct oversight. The level of supervision a student needs is based on the professional judgement of their supervisors, taking into account any associated risks and the students’ knowledge, proficiency and confidence.
*Students aren’t in the staffing numbers, but they are part of the team*

environment for example at an AEI, training provider or specialist centre.
Observation - involves a PS/PA observing a student undertaking a task or series of tasks in the learning environment. As stipulated in NMC legislation (Articles 9(2)(b) and 5(2)(b) of the Nursing and Midwifery Order 2001) ‘good health’ means that the applicant is capable of safe and effective practice either with or without reasonable adjustments. Introduction
The standards of proficiency presented here represent the standards of knowledge and skills that a nursing associate will need to meet in order to be considered by the NMC as capable of safe and effective nursing associate practice. These standards have been designed to apply across all health and care settings.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
1 The nursing associate role is being introduced and regulated in England from 2019. If other countries of the UK decide to use and regulate the role in future it will require a change to our legislation, and the updating of our standards
The proficiencies serve a number of purposes:
They set out for patients and the public what nursing associates know and can do when they join the NMC register.
The standards help nursing associates by providing clarity about their role. Read alongside the nursing standards of proficiency, they demonstrate the synergies and differences between the two roles.
For nurses and other health and care professionals, the standards provide clarity on the knowledge and skills they can reasonably expect all nursing associates to have and this will help inform safe decisions about delegation.
Employers understand what nursing associates can contribute to the health and wellbeing of patients and service users, and can make effective decisions about whether and how to use the role.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.

Employers understand what nursing associates can contribute to the health and wellbeing of patients and service users, and can make effective decisions about whether and how to use the role.
Educators must develop and deliver programmes that equip nursing associates with the skills, knowledge and behaviours needed to meet these standards of proficiency when they qualify.
Nursing associate is a new role being introduced into the health and care workforce in England from 20191. It is a generic role (not defined by a field of nursing) but within the discipline of nursing. Nursing associates are intended to bridge a gap between health and care assistants, and registered nurses.
While the nursing associate role is new, it is particularly important that the public, health and care professionals, and employers can develop an understanding of what nursing associates know and can do.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
www.nmc.org.uk Standards of proficiency for nursing associates 2
Nursing associates are members of the nursing team, who have gained a Foundation Degree, typically involving two years of higher education. They are not nurses; nursing is a graduate entry profession and those joining the nursing part of the NMC register require a degree. Nurses also develop additional skills and knowledge within a specific field of nursing.
Nursing associates are a new profession, accountable for their practice. These proficiencies set out what pre-registration training will equip nursing associates to know, and do. Once they are practising, nursing associates can undertake further education and training and demonstrate additional knowledge and skills, enhancing their competence as other registered professionals routinely do. The roles played by nursing associates will vary from setting to setting, depending on local clinical frameworks, and it may also be shaped by national guidance.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
Nursing associates provide care for people of all ages and from different backgrounds, cultures and beliefs. They provide care for people who have mental, physical, cognitive and behavioural care needs, those living with dementia, the elderly and for people at the end of their life. They must be able to care for people in their own home, in the community or hospital or in any health care settings where their needs are supported and managed. They work in the context of continual change, challenging environments, different models of care delivery, shifting demographics, innovation and rapidly evolving technologies. Increasing integration of health and social care services will require nursing associates to play a proactive role in multidisciplinary teams.
We have designed these proficiencies to align with the latest standards of proficiency for nurses:
To allow people to understand the differences between the two roles
To enable education providers to facilitate educational progression from nursing associate to nurse

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
To allow people to understand the differences between the two roles
To enable education providers to facilitate educational progression from nursing associate to nurse
To demonstrate how the nursing associate role can support the registered nurse, to allow registered nurses to deliver the NMC’s enhanced ‘Future Nurse’ standards of proficiency.
The outcome statements for each platform have been designed to apply across all health and care settings. At the point of registration, nursing associates are required to meet all outcome statements and to demonstrate an awareness of how requirements vary across different health and care settings. As the nursing associate role is generic, students may demonstrate proficiencies in any appropriate context, and there is no expectation that they must be demonstrated in every health and care setting.
In common with all of our regulatory standards and guidance, these proficiencies will be subject to periodic review. The current version of our proficiencies can always be found on our website.

Annexe A: Communication and relationship management skills
Introduction
In order to meet the proficiency outcomes outlined in the main body of this document, nursing associates must be able to demonstrate the communication and relationship management skills described in this annexe at the point of registration.
The ability to communicate effectively, with sensitivity and compassion, and to manage relationships with people is central to the provision of high quality person-centred care. These competencies must be demonstrated in practice settings and adapted to meet the needs of people across their lifespan. Nursing associates need a diverse range of communication skills and strategies to ensure that individuals, their families and carers are supported to be actively involved in their own care wherever appropriate, and that they are kept informed and well prepared.

We regulate nurses, midwives and nursing associates in the UK. We exist to protect the public. We maintain a register of nurses and midwives allowed to practise in the UK.
We make sure nurses, midwives and nursing associates keep their skills and knowledge up to date and uphold our professional standards.
We have clear and transparent processes to investigate people who fall short of our standards.

A Guidance Toolkit for Pre-Registration Adult Nurses, Practice Supervisors, and Practice Assessors
Author: Lincoln Gombedza
Context and Purpose
This toolkit has been developed to support pre-registration Adult Field student nurses, and the Practice Supervisors (PS) and Practice Assessors (PA) who support and guide them in practice learning environments. Its primary purpose is to provide structured guidance, suggestive learning actions, and resources to assist students in evidencing their achievement of the Nursing and Midwifery Council (NMC) proficiencies.1
The content is directly aligned with the NMC Standards of Proficiency for Registered Nurses (2018) 2 and the NMC Standards for Student Supervision and Assessment (SSSA).4
This document is a guidance toolkit, not a formal assessment record. It is intended to be used alongside the student's official local practice assessment documentation (e.g., a Practice Assessment Document (PAD), OnlinePARE, or equivalent electronic system).1
This guidance was created by stakeholders from practice (Practice Education Facilitators), nursing educators, and nursing students.

This toolkit is designed for all stakeholders involved in practice learning and assessment:

Practice Supervisors (PS): To guide you in supporting students day-to-day, providing feedback, and identifying appropriate learning activities.1
Practice Assessors (PA): To support you in making robust, evidence-based assessment decisions about a student's proficiency.1
Academic Assessors (AA): To provide a clear benchmark of practice expectations to inform summative assessment and progression decisions.1
Practice Learning Partners and Academic Staff: To ensure a consistent, high-quality
approach to supervision and assessment across all learning environments.

Guidance and Content
Purpose of the Toolkit
The purpose of this guidance is to provide a structured framework, suggestive methods of assessment, and learning resources to support students in achieving the NMC Standards of Proficiency for Registered Nurses (2018) within the Adult Field of practice.1 It aims to demystify the standards and provide clear, practical examples of how proficiencies can be evidenced in diverse practice settings.
The Three Progression Stages
The pre-registration nursing programme is structured across three parts, or years. While the core proficiencies define the standard for registration, the level of performance expected progresses significantly at each stage. This toolkit defines this progression as follows:
Part / Year 1: Guided participation in care and performing with increasing
confidence. ○ Focus on foundational knowledge, performing fundamental skills under supervision,
and beginning to apply person-centred communication.1
Part / Year 2: Active participation in care with minimal guidance and performing
with increased confidence and competence. ○ Focus on more independent assessment, managing more complex episodes of care,

and safe use of risk assessment tools and equipment.1
Part / Year 3: Practising independently with minimal supervision, and leading and
coordinating care with confidence. ○ Focus on leadership, delegation, coordinating complex multidisciplinary care,
managing complex conversations, and evaluating quality and patient experience.1

This toolkit links each proficiency statement with:
Suggested assessment strategies: Valid methods for evidencing the proficiency (e.g., direct observation, discussion).1
Exemplars of student actions and behaviours: Practical, "suggestive" examples of what the student might do, discuss, or demonstrate.1
Online learning resources: Links to relevant modules (e.g., e-Learning for Healthcare (ELFH), external resources) to support theoretical knowledge.1

To achieve the proficiencies, students must be assessed using a range of methods. The Practice Assessor's final decision is based on a triangulation of evidence. The following methods are all valid ways to demonstrate proficiency.1

Demonstration of proficiency through discussion
Definition: Proficiency is evidenced through a structured discussion that demonstrates the student's underpinning knowledge, clinical reasoning, and reflective ability. This includes discussing research, reflection, and the application of national/local policy.1
When to use: This is essential for assessing cognitive skills (e.g., decision-making,

NMC Standards of Proficiency for Registered Nurses (2018)

The SSSA Roles: PS, PA, and AA
Understanding the different roles is essential for effective practice learning:
Practice Supervisor (PS):
Who: Any registered nurse, midwife, or nursing associate can be a PS. Other
registered health and social care professionals can also undertake this role (e.g., physiotherapist, pharmacist, occupational therapist).1
Role: The PS supports and supervises students on a day-to-day basis, serving as a role model for safe practice.4 They facilitate learning opportunities, ask coaching questions, and provide regular feedback on the student's progress, which they will feed back to the Practice Assessor.1
Practice Assessor (PA):
Who: Must be a registered nurse, midwife, or nursing associate with appropriate equivalent experience for the student's field of practice.1
Role: The PA conducts the formal assessments to confirm the student's achievement of proficiencies and programme outcomes. They do not supervise the student on a day-to-day basis. Their role is to collate and triangulate evidence from various sources to make an objective, evidence-based assessment.1
Academic Assessor (AA):

Role: The AA collates and confirms the student's achievement in the academic

Continuity and Triangulation of Evidence
The SSSA model separates day-to-day supervision (PS) from formal assessment (PA) to improve objectivity. The PA's decision must be based on a "triangulation" of evidence gathered throughout the placement. This includes 1:
Feedback from the Practice Supervisor(s). ● Feedback from other members of the team.
The student's own reflections and documentation (e.g., in their PAD). ● Feedback from service users, their families, and carers. ● Direct observation or discussion by the PA.
The PA must take into account the student's achievement over the whole period of the placement, not just on one single day.1

Coaching and Reflection: The PS should use coaching models to support reflective

Patient safety is paramount. The level of supervision required depends on the student's competence and the risk of the activity.1
Student's Responsibility: Students must "be aware of their current level of competency and only accept delegated tasks for which they have proven competence".1 They must have completed the required university-based theory prior to attempting invasive skills in practice.1
Direct Supervision: This is defined as being "In the immediate presence and under the constant observation of a registered practitioner... who is able to stop the student at any point if deemed necessary".1

Utilising Spoke Opportunities
Definition and Purpose
A "spoke" placement is a short, focused learning opportunity that complements the student's main (or "hub") placement.1 Spoke opportunities are an highly effective way to enhance the learning experience by providing exposure to different parts of the patient journey, specialist services, and the wider multidisciplinary team.1
Spoke placements are particularly valuable "if there is limited exposure to a proficiency in a specific field" in the hub placement. For example, a student on an acute surgical ward may arrange a spoke with a palliative care specialist nurse to gain experience in end-of-life care decision-making.1
Students should be proactive in discussing and arranging spoke opportunities with their Practice Assessor.1

Myth Busters
There are common misconceptions about student assessment. This section clarifies the facts according to the NMC (2018) standards.
Myth vs Fact
Myth: A Practice Assessor is accountable for a student's actions after they have signed them off as proficient.

Myth vs Fact
Myth: A Practice Assessor is accountable for a student's actions after they have signed them off as proficient.
Fact: The Practice Assessor's accountability is for the assessment decision they made at that time, based on the "clear documented evidence" available. The PA is not accountable if a learner "at a later date, demonstrates poor professionalism" or makes an error, provided the original assessment was robust and defensible.1
Myth: A student must complete every single "suggestive action" listed in this toolkit to pass the proficiency.
Fact: The examples are "suggestive, not limited to..." and are not a checklist.1 The student needs to provide sufficient evidence to demonstrate proficiency, which can be achieved through various equivalent activities.
Myth: Only a Registered Nurse (RN) can supervise a student in practice.
Fact: Any NMC registered nurse, midwife, or nursing associate can act as a Practice Supervisor (PS).4 Furthermore, "other registered health and social care professionals" (e.g., OTs, Physiotherapists, Paramedics) can also act as a PS, providing valuable feedback on proficiencies relevant to their scope of practice.1

Myth: Simulation and "discussion" assessments don't count towards proficiencies; only direct, hands-on care does.
Fact: Simulation and discussion are explicitly defined as valid assessment methods.1 For
many high-risk or invasive skills, simulation is the required and safest way to assess initial proficiency.1 Discussion is essential for assessing a student's knowledge, reasoning, and application of policy.1
Myth: A student must achieve every proficiency in every placement.
Fact: This is not expected. The NMC states, "There's no expectation that the proficiencies must be demonstrated in every health and care setting".1 If an opportunity is not available, the proficiency should be left "Blank" and will be assessed in a different environment later in the programme.
Proficiency Clustering
A highly effective and efficient way to evidence proficiencies is through "clustering." Proficiencies do not operate as isolated, stand-alone tasks. A single episode of care, if planned and reflected on appropriately, can demonstrate a wide range of proficiencies simultaneously.1

PCC ACP
This document is designed to support you in gathering the skills and knowledge required from starting your career as a qualified Nurse in Paediatric Critical Care up to the point of ‘readiness to attend a L3 PCC course’. This is described as your Foundation phase. The Foundation phase includes the skills required during a Supervisory period of clinical practice and those required to proceed to PCC course entry.
Beyond the scope of this document there are 3 further phases of practice that you may wish to enter during your PCC career. The second phase includes the completion of a Paediatric Critical Care Course where you will gain the skills and knowledge associated with PCC course completion.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
Following a consolidation period there will be a Specialist Training phase where Clinical Leadership and advanced clinical skills required for senior clinical roles will be introduced. This may include but is not limited to advanced ventilation, advanced Renal replacement Therapies and core skills required to team lead or shift lead in PCC.
Should you decide to move into Advanced Clinical Practice roles there will be competency frameworks supporting the development of specific skills and knowledge required for these roles. Examples of ACP roles include PCC Retrieval, PCC Outreach and PCC Advanced Clinical Practitioner.
Whilst this document provides an outline for the progression of skills and Knowledge in PCC, it does not provide time specific targets. Not only will this vary between individuals but will also be impacted by the specific needs and standards within each trust. Any specific time frames required should be agreed at a local level.
There is also an acknowledgement that variations in specialism and local operational preferences may result in some overlap of the skills and knowledge required at each phase.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Learners are expected to take responsibility for their own learning and commence the assessment process with the self-report column. Here they should confirm they believe themselves to be competent and ready for assessment. The assessor will then document their findings. Competent will be documented as Yes Not competent as No All episodes of assessment should be documented in order to evidence the nature and extent of support and supervision provided in achieving a skill and to provide direction in performance management if repeated assessments are unsuccessful. Formative assessment is used to assess levels of competence after an opportunity of learning. It will provide feedback as to what gaps remain in order to plan further development. Formative assessment is an important step for the learner and assessor to reach a shared understanding of needs and next steps. If the learner is deemed Competent at first assessment there may not be a need for further documented assessment although some clinical skills in particular may be beneficial to assess twice if there is likely to be variations in performance or adaptions required to perform the same skill in a different situation.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.

Summative assessment provides a conclusion to an episode of learning and skill acquisition. Both learner and assessor are required to report ‘Yes’ in order for the individual to be deemed competent in this skill. Skills have been written as singular stand alone skills that can be completed in a progressive and positive way rather than in a detailed description encompassing all knowledge, and a variety of clinical skills in relation to 1 area of competence. The benchmark for competence is therefore more specific with less variation in assessment as long as attention is paid to the specific description.

Progress Trackers explained
The Foundation competencies are divided into Supervisory and PCC Course readiness. Progress Trackers allow the learner and assessors to easily see at a glance the progress towards completion of each element. Period of completion and designated supernumerary time are at the discretion of local teams.
Supervisory Period – Normally directly supervised by an established Critical Care nurse for a period of time to enable development of the essential skills required to care independently for a child requiring critical care. There is a variety in the length of supervisory periods given to nursing staff new to this specialty depending on which Paediatric Critical Care Unit they work and the previous clinical experience. This is the basic level of competence expected before independent practice. However, some units will make adaptions in the way that supervision is provided with concepts such as ‘team Nursing’ or ‘Pod Nursing’ beyond the supernumerary period. Skills to be completed in Supervisory are highlighted red.

Alternatively, it may be useful to consider a spoke placement if there is limited exposure to the proficiency in the practice learning environment.

Scope of Practice
What does scope of practice mean in this context?
Does the learning environment /experience deliver nursing care to a spectrum of patients and their needs, if so then scope of practice can be applied, for example: a Registered Nurse (adult field) working on a frailty unit in an acute hospital dealing regularly with dementia patients as well, would have a scope of practice to support a learner studying a nursing mental health pathway.
The mental health learner could even bring their knowledge and experience to the environment to enhance patient’s experience/care.

There are a number of different learning experiences that can be delivered within learning environments, using different methods such as group learning, one to one learning, peer to peer learning, classroom learning, simulation and direct patient care.

Learning experiences do not need to be confined within a particular environment, or to a particular episode of care. A learning experience can follow a person’s episode or experience of care and can involve a leaner being assigned to a service user throughout their treatment or care, across environments. Learning can be organised in lots of different ways. For example, group or one to one supervised learning, providing direct care, simulated activity, or independent or self-directed learning.

Accountability/Signing of PAD If a learner has or can provide evidence to the Practice Supervisors and/or Practice Assessor that, at that time, confirms to them the learning has been achieved and they document this in the relevant documentation (PAD) then there is clear evidence base for the decision of the Practice Assessor. If a learner then, at a later date, demonstrates poor professionalism (or anything else against the Code) then it is not the accountability of the Practice Assessor as they have clear documented evidence their assessment was appropriate at that time.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
Assessment responsibilities Each practice assessor is responsible for the assessment and confirmation of the achievement of proficiencies and programmes outcomes in practice learning for the student(s) they are assigned to, for the period they are assigned to them. A good assessment is evidenced based, objective and fair, taking into account a variety of views and inputs, and student diversity, such as different learning styles, cultural backgrounds and communication styles. The practice assessor should take into account the student’s history of achievement and their achievement across theory and practice. Assessment should be continuous throughout the time in which a practice assessor is assigned to a student. The practice assessor should be up to date on the progress of the student they are assigned to; collation of information on a student’s performance should be managed in a way that enables this. Feedback to the student about their achievement and collaborating with them to review possible areas for improvement also forms a fundamental part of the assessment process. We do this via the PAD/OAR.

When contributing to the recommendation for progression practice assessors should take into account the student’s achievement over the whole period for which they are making the decision, e.g. a placement or a year. They should also consider the student’s achievement in previous parts of the programme (if any) and how they have progressed over the programme.
Once they have assessed the student’s practice learning for the placement(s) they are assigned to the student, they should ensure that there is a proper handover to the next practice assessor, and any other relevant people involved in the education of the student. This includes ensuring that all relevant documentation is up to date, and any particular issues with the student’s performance have been recorded or communicated with the next practice assessor and all relevant people.

Approved education institutions (AEIs)
The status awarded by the NMC to an institution, or part of an institution, or combination of institutions that works in partnership with practice placement and work placed learning providers. Practice assessors conduct assessments to confirm student achievement of proficiencies and programme outcomes for practice learning. Assessment decisions by practice assessors are informed by feedback sought and received from practice supervisors. Practice assessors make and record objective, evidenced-based assessments on conduct, proficiency, and achievement. Students may be supervised by other registered health and social care professionals.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.

Supernumerary
Students in practice or work placed learning must be supported to learn without being counted as part of the staffing required for safe and effective care in that setting. For apprentices, this includes practice placements within their place of employment; this does not apply when they are working in their substantive role. Placements should enable students to learn to provide safe and effective care, not merely to observe; students can and should add real value to care. The contribution students make will increase over time as they gain proficiency, and they will continue to benefit from ongoing guidance and feedback. Once a student has demonstrated that they are proficient, they should be able to fulfil tasks without direct oversight. The level of supervision a student needs is based on the professional judgement of their supervisors, taking into account any associated risks and the students’ knowledge, proficiency and confidence. *Students aren’t in the staffing numbers, but they are part of the team*

Observation - involves a PS/PA observing a student undertaking a task or series of tasks in the learning environment. This should be complemented by questioning from the PS/PA during or/and after the observation. Observational assessment is deemed the most appropriate assessment method for practical skills; by watching the student complete a task, they can demonstrate their competence.

(Good) health and character requirements

Author: Lincoln Gombedza Supporting Adult Field pre-registration nurses in evidencing NMC proficiencies and skills in practice.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
Nursing students practice clinical skills in a simulation lab, which is a safe environment to develop proficiency. This digital toolkit is designed to support adult field nursing students, their Practice Supervisors (PS), Practice Assessors (PA), and Academic Assessors in UK practice learning environments. Aligned with the Nursing & Midwifery Council (NMC) Standards of Proficiency for Registered Nurses (2018) – including Annexes A and B – it provides structured guidance on achieving and evidencing required proficiencies and skills. The toolkit offers example actions, suggested assessment methods, and links to online learning resources for each proficiency. It is intended to be used alongside local practice assessment documentation (e.g. Practice Assessment Document, PAD) to guide learning and assessment in practice. This document is practice-facing and can be adapted by Approved Education Institutions (AEIs) or practice partners to fit local context. Its ultimate purpose is to facilitate coaching conversations, empower students in their learning, and ensure all proficiencies (clinical and professional) are met in a supportive, equitable manner.
User Guide

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
User Guide
Intended Users: This toolkit is for pre-registration nursing students (Adult field) and those supervising or assessing them in practice – namely Practice Supervisors, Practice Assessors, and Academic Assessors. Academic staff and practice education facilitators may also find it useful to support students. The content is organized by programme Part/Year (1, 2, 3) so that users can navigate to guidance appropriate for the student’s level of study. Each Part corresponds to increasing proficiency: Part 1 (Year 1) foundational skills under guidance, Part 2 (Year 2) more independent practice with minimal guidance, and Part 3 (Year 3) leading care with minimal supervision (detailed in the Introduction below). The toolkit can be read sequentially or section-by-section as needed.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
Grade Descriptors: In students’ formal assessment documents, proficiencies are typically signed off with the descriptors ‘Yes’, ‘No’, or left blank. ‘Yes’ indicates the proficiency has been achieved, ‘No’ indicates it has not been achieved, and a blank means the proficiency was not assessed or not applicable in that placement[1][2]. Practice Assessors should use their professional judgment to determine achievement. A ‘No’ should trigger supportive actions to help the student improve before the end of the part. If a proficiency cannot be assessed due to the nature of the placement (e.g. a skill not encountered), it should remain blank and can be addressed later or in simulation – there is no requirement to force every proficiency in every setting[3]. Assessors and students
should plan early to ensure opportunities to meet each outcome, including arranging alternative experiences if needed.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
should plan early to ensure opportunities to meet each outcome, including arranging alternative experiences if needed.
Using Example Actions: Each proficiency in this toolkit is accompanied by suggested actions – concrete examples of how a student might demonstrate that proficiency. These are guidance, not a mandatory checklist. A student does not need to complete every example action to achieve the proficiency[4]. Instead, the examples illustrate possible approaches. Students and supervisors are encouraged to come up with other equivalent actions relevant to their setting. The focus should remain on the outcome (the proficiency) rather than ticking off tasks. This flexible approach ensures that evidence can be tailored to the individual patient case or placement context, fostering a more holistic and meaningful achievement of competence.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Coaching and Empowerment: Practice Supervisors are encouraged to use a coaching style in day-to-day supervision – asking questions, prompting students to think critically, and gradually increasing their responsibilities. This empowers students to take ownership of their learning and builds confidence. For example, rather than simply showing how to do a task, a supervisor might ask, “How do you think we should approach this patient’s wound dressing?” and guide the student through their reasoning. This approach aligns with the NMC’s emphasis on students learning independence and autonomy in a safe manner[5]. Positive reinforcement and timely, constructive feedback are key to building the student’s competence and professional identity.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Reasonable Adjustments: In line with equality and human rights legislation, reasonable adjustments should be made to support students with disabilities or specific learning needs. This may include adaptive equipment, modified schedules, or alternative ways to demonstrate a skill. The goal is to provide equal opportunity for all students to achieve the proficiencies, without lowering the standard required. Practice educators should work with university disability support and follow local policies to implement adjustments. For example, a student with hearing impairment might use an amplified stethoscope for assessment skills, or a student with dyslexia might be given additional time for written documentation tasks. Such adjustments ensure compliance with the Equality Act and uphold the NMC’s values of fairness and inclusivity, while maintaining patient safety. Open communication between the student, academic staff, and practice supervisors is essential to identify needs early and plan support.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
Navigation by Part/Year: The toolkit is divided into Parts 1, 2, and 3, corresponding to the three years of a typical nursing programme. Within each Part, you will find a table listing proficiencies relevant to that stage, along with suggested assessment methods, example actions, and e-learning resources. Users can scroll to the section for the student’s current Part to focus on appropriate proficiencies. It’s expected that Part 1 proficiencies are achieved with guidance, Part 2 with increasing independence, and Part 3 at an entry-level registered nurse standard. However, learning is cumulative: skills from Part 1 continue to be refined in later years. Additionally, some higher-level skills may be introduced in Part 2 but only required by Part 3 – these are marked with an asterisk (*) to indicate they can be
completed in the final year if not achieved earlier. Throughout, the toolkit emphasizes quality of learning over quantity of tasks. Students should use it to identify learning goals, and supervisors/assessors can use it to facilitate learning conversations, plan learning experiences, and verify competence via multiple forms of evidence.
Guidance and Content Introduction

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
Guidance and Content Introduction
Purpose and Structure: This toolkit serves as a bridge between the NMC’s high-level standards and everyday practice learning. It breaks down broad proficiencies into practice-focused guidance, ensuring students and supervisors understand how to evidence each outcome. The content is structured first by general guidance sections (assessment methods, key NMC statements, supervision guidance, etc.), followed by the detailed proficiency lists for each Part of the programme. This introductory section clarifies expectations for progression across the three Parts and explains how the toolkit incorporates NMC Annexe skills and procedures.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Progression Expectations: Over the three Parts of the nursing programme, students are expected to progress from guided participation to independence and leadership. In Part 1 (Year 1), students participate in care under close guidance, focusing on fundamental skills and building confidence. By Part 2 (Year 2), students take a more active role in care with minimal guidance, performing skills with increased confidence and competence[6]. In Part 3 (Year 3), students should be practising independently with minimal supervision and leading and coordinating care with confidence[7]. This staged progression reflects the increasing complexity of proficiencies: Year 1 emphasizes core skills (communication, basic assessments, personal care, infection control, etc.), Year 2 adds more complex skills (clinical decision-making, managing care for multiple patients, some invasive procedures under supervision), and Year 3 focuses on leadership (team coordination, delegation, autonomous decision-making, and handling complex or rapidly changing situations). The toolkit sections for each Part are designed with this in mind – for instance, Part 3 guidance includes proficiencies related to leadership and

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: handling complex or rapidly changing situations). The toolkit sections for each Part are designed with this in mind – for instance, Part 3 guidance includes proficiencies related to leadership and complex care coordination that would be inappropriate for a first-year student. Practice Assessors should ensure that by the end of Part 3, the student is functioning at the level of an entry- level registered nurse across all platforms of proficiency.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Annexe B Procedures and Field-Specific Application: The NMC’s Annexes to the Standards of Proficiency outline specific skills and procedures that all new nurses must be able to demonstrate. Annexe A covers communication and relationship management skills, and Annexe B covers a broad range of clinical nursing procedures. The procedures in Annexe B are divided into sections (often referred to as Part 1 and Part 2 of Annexe B). Importantly, Annexe B procedures are additional to the main proficiency statements – they support and underpin the proficiencies but are not proficiencies in themselves[8]. At the point of registration, an adult nurse must be able to safely demonstrate all the procedures listed in Annexe B, meaning give a practical demonstration or clearly explain how to perform them, providing evidence such as performing the skill in practice, simulation, or via discussion and reflection[9].

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: The NMC expects that Annexe B procedures be assessed in the student’s own field of practice whenever practicable[10]. “Practicable” means if it can be done in that context, it should be – acknowledging that opportunities will vary by placement[11]. For adult field students, most Annexe B skills (e.g. taking vital signs, wound care, medication administration) will naturally occur in adult care settings. Some procedures that are more common in other fields (e.g. care of a child or mental health specific interventions) are still required knowledge, but adult students would demonstrate them at an appropriate level for adult care[12][13]. Conversely, students from other fields might fulfill adult-oriented procedures through simulation or spoke placements. For example, an adult nursing student needs to understand mental health interventions (like de-escalation techniques or cognitive therapies) and may encounter these if an adult patient has those needs, but they are not expected to become expert mental health clinicians – just competent to recognize and support those needs or seek help appropriately[14]. Where a certain procedure is not available in the student’s placement (for

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: become expert mental health clinicians – just competent to recognize and support those needs or seek help appropriately[14]. Where a certain procedure is not available in the student’s placement (for instance, an adult student in general practice may not see chest drain management), the student can demonstrate it through simulation or during an alternative experience.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: This toolkit links each proficiency to relevant Annexe B skills where applicable. By following the suggestions, students should inherently cover Annexe B requirements. For instance, a proficiency about maintaining a patient’s airway will naturally involve demonstrating or simulating airway management procedures (an Annexe B skill). It should be noted that some Annexe B procedures might only be achievable given the right circumstances. Not every placement will provide exposure to every procedure (for example, not all adult placements will have patients requiring NG tube insertion). In such cases, different assessment methods can be used to achieve these procedures, such as simulation, case studies, or spoke visits[11]. The toolkit encourages creative strategies – a list of which is provided in the next section – to ensure all procedures are eventually demonstrated by the completion of the programme. In summary, the toolkit helps ensure that field-specific application of Annexe B is achieved: adult nursing students will meet all Annexe B skills relevant to adult care in practice, and for those that are less common in adult settings, alternative methods will be used so that nothing

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: adult nursing students will meet all Annexe B skills relevant to adult care in practice, and for those that are less common in adult settings, alternative methods will be used so that nothing is missed. This integrated approach keeps the focus on holistic nurse competency, producing graduates who are proficient in core skills of their own field and conversant with care needs across other fields[15][16].

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
Suggestive Methods of Assessment
Proficiencies can be demonstrated and assessed in various ways. The following methods are commonly used, often in combination, to gather evidence that a student has achieved a given outcome. Deciding which method is appropriate depends on the nature of the skill or knowledge, as well as opportunities available in the placement. The student’s Practice Assessor will make the final assessment decision, informed by evidence from these methods.
Direct Observation: The student performs the skill or task in the practice setting while a registered practitioner observes. This is the most straightforward way to
assess many clinical skills. For example, a student’s hand hygiene technique or blood pressure measurement should be assessed by directly watching them do it[17]. Direct observation provides first-hand evidence and can be supplemented by questions to confirm understanding (the “underpinning knowledge”). A proficiency demonstrated via direct observation is considered achieved once the observer (e.g. a nurse) confirms the student performed it safely and effectively[18][19]. This method is ideal for technical and interpersonal skills.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Demonstration through Discussion: The student explains, describes or answers questions about how they would perform a skill or handle a scenario, drawing on knowledge and maybe past experiences. This method is useful when actual performance opportunities are limited or when probing the student’s depth of understanding. For instance, a student might discuss how they would recognise and respond to sepsis, referencing current guidelines, even if they haven’t encountered an septic patient yet. Through professional conversation, including reflective accounts or reference to research and local policy, the student can demonstrate their proficiency in a cognitive sense[20][21]. If using this method, the Practice Supervisor/Assessor should ensure the discussion is robust and scenario- based, and document that the student showed sufficient knowledge to meet the outcome.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Simulation: Simulation involves re-creating clinical scenarios in a controlled environment (or sometimes within the placement) so that the student can practice and be assessed without risk to real patients. This can range from high-fidelity simulations (using manikins or actors in a sim lab) to simple role-play or scenario- based drills. Simulation is recognised by the NMC as a valid way to achieve practice hours and proficiencies, provided it is structured and supervised appropriately[22]. An effective simulation allows for repetition, feedback, and reflection[23]. For proficiency sign-off, a registered practitioner would observe the student’s performance in simulation and assess it as if in real practice[24]. For example, if a placement never encountered a cardiac arrest, a simulation of CPR can be used to demonstrate that proficiency. Simulation is especially helpful for invasive procedures like cannulation or catheterisation if real opportunities are scarce – the student can show the steps on a manikin to an assessor. It’s also used for emergency scenarios, communication exercises (like breaking bad news with an actor), and other situations to build confidence. Documentation

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: the steps on a manikin to an assessor. It’s also used for emergency scenarios, communication exercises (like breaking bad news with an actor), and other situations to build confidence. Documentation of simulation should note the scenario and how the student performed.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Spoke Placement / Training Opportunity: A spoke is a short visit or placement in an area outside the student’s main “hub” placement, designed to give exposure to specific learning opportunities. Students might arrange a spoke of a day or a week with a relevant team to meet a particular outcome. For instance, if a student’s main placement is surgical ward but they need experience with community wound care, a spoke day with a wound clinic can provide that. Spoke placements are coordinated with the help of Practice Educators or facilitators and must have

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: appropriate supervision. Evidence from a spoke could be an observation by a practitioner in that area, or a feedback testimonial. Spokes are particularly useful for proficiencies that are difficult to achieve in the main placement due to limited exposure[25]. For example, “a mental health nursing student may arrange an ‘out of field’ spoke placement to participate in the care of a patient requiring urethral catheterisation”[26] – similarly, an adult field student could do a spoke in a neonatal unit to observe infant feeding techniques, or in a community setting to understand social care assessments. Spoke opportunities also include attending training sessions (e.g. a diabetes pump workshop or moving & handling training) and area-based learning like specialist nurse clinics. The evidence is often a signed observation or certificate of completion. This method broadens the student’s experience and fosters interdepartmental and interagency understanding.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Feedback (Service Users, Carers, Staff): Feedback is a valuable form of evidence for proficiencies related to communication, professionalism, and caring behaviors. It involves gathering input from those who have interacted with the student – this could be patients and their families, or other healthcare team members. For instance, a patient might provide feedback that a student communicated with empathy and kept them well-informed during their care, which could evidence a communication proficiency. Similarly, a physiotherapist might give feedback that a student proactively assisted in mobility sessions and followed guidance well, evidencing teamwork. Feedback should be documented (e.g. via feedback forms or testimonials) and can corroborate the student’s performance in less directly observable areas like compassion and advocacy[27][28]. While feedback alone may not confirm technical skill, it enriches the evidence, especially when combined with observation or discussion. Triangulating evidence – i.e., using feedback alongside the assessor’s own observations and the student’s reflection – provides a stronger, more holistic basis for assessment decisions.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
These methods are not mutually exclusive. In fact, the strongest evidence often comes from a combination. For example, a student might directly observe a complex wound dressing in the morning, then later have a discussion with their supervisor to explain the rationale and what they learned, supplemented by a reflection they write and perhaps some feedback from the patient about their communication. All of this together demonstrates the proficiency comprehensively. Practice Assessors are encouraged to be flexible and use all available evidence when signing off proficiencies, in line with NMC guidance that assessment should be objective, evidence-based, and drawing on feedback from supervisors[29].
NMC Key Statements
Contemporary nursing practice and education in the UK are governed by several key NMC standards and guidelines. Below is a summary of the foundational documents and principles that inform this toolkit, providing context and rationale for the expectations placed on students and supervisors:

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Future Nurse: Standards of Proficiency for Registered Nurses (NMC, 2018): This is the core document detailing what newly qualified registered nurses must know and be able to do. It is structured into seven platforms (domains) of proficiency – ranging from being an accountable professional to coordinating care – which apply across all fields of nursing[16][30]. The standards emphasize that registered nurses must provide coordinated, compassionate, evidence-based, person-centred care to people of all ages and in all settings[31]. They highlight the importance of nurses working autonomously and collaboratively within interdisciplinary teams[32]. The proficiencies are outcome-focused and designed to reflect modern healthcare needs, including areas like mental health, public health, and leadership in every nurse’s role. Notably, the 2018 standards require that students develop proficiency not only in their own field (e.g. Adult) but also an understanding of care across other fields – for example, adult nurses should be aware of mental health needs and vice versa[14]. The standards are accompanied by Annexe A and Annexe B which list specific communication skills and nursing procedures

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: example, adult nurses should be aware of mental health needs and vice versa[14]. The standards are accompanied by Annexe A and Annexe B which list specific communication skills and nursing procedures that underpin the broader outcomes[16]. Together, these standards set the benchmark for registration; this toolkit is organized around ensuring students meet these proficiencies in practice.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Annexe B – Nursing Procedures: Annexe B (part of the above standards) specifies a comprehensive list of clinical procedures that all registered nurses must be able to perform safely by entry to the register[33]. These include procedures for assessing, delivering and evaluating care – such as taking vital signs, administering injections, performing wound care, managing nutrition and hydration (including enteral feeding), urinary catheterisation, venepuncture, cannulation, managing IV infusions, blood transfusions, and more. The key principle is that these procedures must be demonstrated effectively and with compassion, reflecting evidence-based practice and an understanding of the person’s holistic needs (e.g., cultural considerations, communication during the procedure)[34]. The NMC clarifies that “at the point of registration, the nurse will be able to safely demonstrate the following procedures” – meaning students can be assessed on these in any appropriate setting (clinical or simulated) before qualifying[35]. Annexe B is not separate from the proficiencies but an extension ensuring that the “hands-on” skills backing the proficiencies are covered[8]. Different fields of nursing

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: before qualifying[35]. Annexe B is not separate from the proficiencies but an extension ensuring that the “hands-on” skills backing the proficiencies are covered[8]. Different fields of nursing will emphasize different procedures (for instance, mental health settings might not have many IV insertions), so the NMC allows flexibility: procedures should be assessed in the student’s own field where practicable, and if not, in an alternative context[10]. The Annexe B content is woven into this toolkit’s Part 1–3 tables so that by the end of Part 3, all these skills have been addressed.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Standards for Student Supervision and Assessment (NMC, 2018): Often abbreviated as SSSA, these standards replaced the old mentorship standards and introduced the distinct roles of Practice Supervisor, Practice Assessor, and Academic Assessor. The SSSA outlines how students should be supported in

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: practice and how assessment decisions should be made. Practice Supervisors are registered professionals (nurses, midwives, nursing associates – and even other registered health and social care professionals) who facilitate learning and supervise students day-to-day[5][36]. All registered nurses can be supervisors – it’s a role that focuses on being a role model and providing feedback. Practice Assessors are registered nurses (for nursing students, they must be same field) who conduct assessments to confirm whether students have achieved proficiencies and outcomes[29]. A practice assessor is assigned to the student and, informed by supervisors’ input, makes objective decisions about student progression[37]. Academic Assessors (usually a university lecturer) work in partnership with the practice assessor to review the student’s overall progress and recommend progression to the next Part or to qualification[38]. Key principles from SSSA include: students must be supervised in practice at all times appropriate to their learning needs[39]; supervisors provide constructive feedback and serve as role models[40]; assessors conduct fair and evidence-based assessments, and there must be

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: at all times appropriate to their learning needs[39]; supervisors provide constructive feedback and serve as role models[40]; assessors conduct fair and evidence-based assessments, and there must be good communication between practice and academic assessors to triangulate student performance[41][42]. Additionally, SSSA requires that those in these roles are prepared and supported – e.g., new practice assessors should be orientated to their role. This toolkit’s guidance on supervision (section below) is grounded in these standards, ensuring that the processes of student support and assessment uphold NMC requirements.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: The Code: Professional Standards of Practice and Behaviour for Nurses, Midwives and Nursing Associates (NMC, 2018): Commonly known as “the NMC Code,” this is an essential document that all registered nurses (and students, as nurses in training) must adhere to. It’s structured around four key principles: Prioritise People, Practise Effectively, Preserve Safety, and Promote Professionalism and Trust[43]. The Code underpins everything a nurse does. For example, prioritising people means putting the interests of those in your care first, treating them with kindness, respect and compassion, and upholding their dignity. Practising effectively involves delivering care based on the best evidence, communicating clearly, and working cooperatively with colleagues. Preserving safety means acting within your competence, preventing harm, and speaking up if safety is compromised. Promoting professionalism and trust covers behaving with integrity, upholding the reputation of the profession, and being accountable for your actions. In the context of practice assessment, students are expected to demonstrate professional behaviors in line with the Code, such as maintaining confidentiality, seeking

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: accountable for your actions. In the context of practice assessment, students are expected to demonstrate professional behaviors in line with the Code, such as maintaining confidentiality, seeking consent, and reflecting on feedback. Serious breaches of the Code (like poor attitude, dishonesty, or unsafe practice) would result in a student not achieving proficiencies regardless of technical skill. The Code is thus a constant point of reference – supervisors and assessors should coach students on Code principles and may use it as a framework when giving feedback (“e.g., how did the student prioritize the patient’s comfort?” or “did they speak up about a potential safety issue?”). Adherence to the Code is non-negotiable; it’s also part of what the

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: practice assessor must consider when signing off a student’s fitness for progression.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Standards Framework for Nursing and Midwifery Education (NMC, 2018): This is a set of standards that all AEIs and their practice partners must meet in delivering NMC-approved education programmes. It ensures the programmes have effective governance, curricula, student support, and quality improvement processes. In practice terms, these standards guarantee things like: students will experience a learning culture that is safe, inclusive and supportive; there will be collaborative relationships between universities and placement providers; students’ competence is assessed fairly and validly; and educators are suitably qualified. For example, one theme in the framework is about the learning culture – it should empower students and ensure equality and diversity principles are upheld[44][45]. Another part of the framework stipulates that programmes must have robust procedures to address issues like poor performance or academic misconduct. While students and supervisors may not interact with the framework directly, it works behind the scenes to assure the quality of placement learning. If a student feels unsupported or encounters discrimination, that would violate this framework and

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: with the framework directly, it works behind the scenes to assure the quality of placement learning. If a student feels unsupported or encounters discrimination, that would violate this framework and should be addressed. The framework also drives the idea of co-production in education – involving stakeholders, including students and service users, in designing and evaluating programmes[46][47]. In summary, the Standards Framework is about the environment and systems around the student, ensuring they have the resources and conditions needed to achieve the proficiencies. This toolkit in itself is an example of supporting resources that arise from those standards – providing clear guidance to help every student succeed.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
By familiarizing themselves with these key NMC documents, students and practice staff can better understand why certain proficiencies and assessment processes are in place. The ultimate goal of all these standards is to ensure that upon registration, the nurse is safe, competent, and confident to deliver high-quality care. This toolkit translates those expectations into practical guidance for day-to-day learning in the clinical environment.
Guidance for Supervision of Student Nurses
High-quality supervision is critical in practice learning. The NMC’s Standards for student supervision and assessment (SSSA) set out clear roles and responsibilities to ensure students are supported and assessed fairly. Below is guidance on how Practice Supervisors, Practice Assessors, and Academic Assessors should collaborate, as well as expectations for documentation, coaching, managing concerns, and ensuring robust evidence for assessment:

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Roles and Responsibilities: Every nursing student is supervised in practice by at least one Practice Supervisor (often many over time) and has a designated Practice Assessor for a given period (e.g., a placement or year), as well as an Academic Assessor for each part of the programme[48][38].

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Practice Supervisor (PS): A Practice Supervisor is any registered professional (commonly a nurse, but can be midwife, nursing associate or other registered health/social care professional) who works with the student and supports their learning on a day-to-day basis. All registered nurses are capable of being practice supervisors – there is no longer a requirement for a specific mentorship qualification to supervise[5]. The PS role is to enable the student to learn while ensuring safe care. Supervisors serve as role models by demonstrating best practice in their clinical work[49][50]. They provide guidance, answer questions, allow the student to observe and then perform skills under appropriate oversight. A PS should tailor the level of supervision to the student’s competence and confidence: for a new student, this might mean direct close supervision; for a more experienced student, it could mean granting more autonomy but still checking in regularly[51][52]. Practice Supervisors are expected to give timely, constructive feedback to students about their progress toward proficiencies[53]. For example, a PS might debrief with the student after a wound dressing to discuss what went

For example, a PS might debrief with the student after a wound dressing to discuss what went well and what could be improved. They also liaise with the Practice Assessor, sharing observations and insights about the student. Importantly, any patient care performed by a student remains the responsibility of the supervisor overseeing them at that time; the student is not counted in staffing numbers. Supervisors should be familiar with the student’s learning objectives and the proficiencies they need, helping create learning opportunities (e.g., arranging for the student to accompany a specialist nurse if relevant). If a supervisor has any concerns about a student’s practice (e.g., unsafe technique or unprofessional behavior), they must address it immediately (to preserve safety) and inform the Practice Assessor so that appropriate support or action can be taken[54][55].

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Practice Assessor (PA): A Practice Assessor is a registered nurse (for nursing students, specifically in the same field of practice, i.e. adult) who is responsible for assessing and signing off the student’s achievements in practice for a given part of the programme[56][49]. Each student is assigned a practice assessor – often this might be one of the nurses on their ward or placement who has taken on the assessor role and usually does not simultaneously supervise the student day-to- day (to maintain objectivity)[57]. The PA’s job is to periodically review the student’s progress (through midpoint and final interviews or assessments), consider feedback from various supervisors, and ultimately decide if the student has met the required proficiencies and outcomes for that placement or part[58][59]. Assessment decisions by practice assessors must be evidence-based and documented[58][60]. This means the PA should gather and consider multiple sources of evidence: their own observations of the student, feedback from practice supervisors or other colleagues, the student’s reflections, skills logs, and any patient feedback.
