instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Academic Assessor (AA): The Academic Assessor is typically a university faculty member (such as a nursing lecturer) who is assigned to the student for a part of the programme. Their role is to oversee the student’s academic progress and link this with practice progress. At designated points (often end-of-part boards or progression meetings), the academic assessor reviews the student’s academic work and the practice assessor’s recommendations, and then confirms that the student has met all requirements to move forward or graduate[38][63]. The AA and PA are expected to communicate in order to evaluate the whole picture of the student’s performance[64][65]. For example, if a student struggled in practice but excelled academically (or vice versa), the AA and PA would discuss to ensure consistency in judging competence. The Academic Assessor also provides academic support and can help interpret or advise on NMC standards, ensuring the practice assessment is in line with educational standards. Students should know who their academic assessor is and can approach them if any issues arise that straddle academic and practice aspects. For example, if a student had extenuating circumstances affecting both coursework and placement, the AA would coordinate with practice colleagues on how to manage this. In essence, the AA validates the practice assessment from the school’s side and contributes to decisions like whether a student needs a remedial placement or whether they can enter the final placement, etc., in line with program standards[48].

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Supervision in Practice: From the first day in a placement, a student should be introduced to the team and have identified supervisors each shift (one of whom is their point of contact). The NMC requires that students are always supervised according to their learning needs – initially directly, and later maybe indirectly (where the supervisor is available but not physically with the student at every moment) as appropriate[51]. A good strategy is for the student and supervisor at the start of a shift to agree which activities the student will do independently, which with direct oversight, and which not at all if beyond scope. For example, a Year 3 student might administer oral medications under distant supervision (checked but not hovered over), whereas a Year 1 student would do it only by observing or with step-by-step guidance. Supervisors should use judgement: if the student is safe to attempt a skill, let them, but be ready to step in if needed. The goal is to gradually increase the student’s autonomy while ensuring patient safety. Each day, supervisors should also provide brief feedback – what went well, any tips for improvement – and if possible, allow the student time for

Each day, supervisors should also provide brief feedback – what went well, any tips for improvement – and if possible, allow the student time for reflection or skills practice during quieter moments. All supervision and teaching should be documented in the student’s log (many PADs have a section for “Learning summary” each day). If a student is not getting enough exposure to certain proficiencies due to the nature of the environment, supervisors and the student should flag this early to the Practice Assessor so alternate arrangements (like spokes or simulations) can be made.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Documentation Expectations: Practice Assessors are responsible for completing the official assessment documentation (such as the PAD or electronic equivalent like OnlinePARE) to record decisions on proficiency achievement. This documentation should be done accurately and in a timely manner[62]. Delaying documentation can jeopardize a student’s progression, since universities need the completed records to allow the student to move on. A recommended approach is for the PA to document midway feedback (mid-point interview form) and final decisions (final interview) with clear rationale, especially if any proficiency is marked 'No' or concerns exist. Any proficiency signed as achieved (Yes) should ideally have some evidence noted – for instance, “Achieved – observed managing 2 patients’ care over 2 weeks with positive feedback from staff”. PAs should also verify that all required fields are completed: attendance hours, patient feedback forms, reflective journals, etc., as per local assessment documents (like MORA, if midwifery; PAD for nursing, etc.). In practice, many regions use electronic systems; PAs must ensure they have access and sign-offs are done before deadlines. Handover

Handover between Assessors: If a student moves to a new placement or a new PA takes over, a handover of progress should occur[66]. The previous PA’s notes and any action plans should be communicated so the next PA is aware of ongoing goals or issues. This continuity helps avoid repeating interventions or missing ongoing concerns.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Coaching Approach: As mentioned in the User Guide, adopting a coaching model of supervision helps build students’ critical thinking and confidence. Practice Supervisors can use the “ask-tell” balance: ask the student first what they think or how they would proceed, then tell or guide as needed. Techniques like the OSCAR or GROW coaching models (Goal, Reality, Options, Will) can be used informally in practice – e.g., “What do you think is the priority for this patient right now?” (Goal), “What have you noticed about

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: their condition?” (Reality), “What could we do next?” (Options) and then “Okay, try doing X and I’ll support you” (Way forward). Such dialogue encourages active learning. Students often report that being allowed to try (within safe limits) and then getting constructive feedback is most beneficial. A coaching culture also means seeing mistakes or knowledge gaps as learning opportunities rather than simply failures. If a student does something incorrectly (but no harm done because supervisor was present), the supervisor can debrief: “Let’s talk through that – what went wrong and how to do it differently next time.” This approach, rather than scolding, maintains psychological safety for the student, which ironically encourages them to be more open about limitations and thus learn more. Practice Assessors can also coach in their periodic reviews, guiding the student to self- assess (“Which proficiencies are you most concerned about? How can we get you there?”) and helping them create their own action plans. Empowering students in this way aligns with the NMC’s push for autonomous, reflective practitioners.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Handling Concerns and Action Planning: If at any point a supervisor or assessor becomes concerned that a student is not meeting expectations or is unsafe, it is vital to address it early. Do not wait until the final week to raise issues. The first step is usually an informal conversation with the student to clarify expectations and hear their perspective – perhaps there are underlying issues (stress, personal difficulties, lack of knowledge) that can be solved. If the issue is minor (e.g., struggling with a skill), targeted support can be given. For more significant concerns (e.g., frequent medication errors or attitude problems), the Practice Assessor should be informed immediately. Together with the Academic Assessor or link tutor, they may decide to initiate a formal Action Plan or “learning contract.” This written plan will outline: the specific areas of concern, the improvement goals, actions the student must take, what support will be provided, and a timeline for review. For example, an action plan could state: “Proficiency: Administration of medications – Concern: Student has difficulty performing dosage calculations accurately. Action: Student to complete drug calculation

Action: Student to complete drug calculation e-learning module and have 3 supervised med rounds focusing on calculations. Support: Supervisor X will tutor on calculations 1:1. Review: check progress after one week, by [date].” Such plans should be agreed and signed by student and assessor, and a copy given to the Academic Assessor/AEI. If improvement is not seen by the review, the issue is escalated – possibly extending placement, involving a Practice Education Facilitator, or, if safety is at risk, temporarily withdrawing the student from practice for remediation. Throughout, documentation is crucial: keep records of meetings, action plans, and outcomes. This not only guides the student but also provides evidence in case a fail decision is challenged. It’s also important to note that if a student displays any behavior that breaches the Code (like dishonesty or misconduct), that should be escalated to academic leadership immediately, as it may require investigation per university fitness-to-practise procedures.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Triangulation of Evidence: Practice Assessors should use a holistic view when assessing a student – meaning not relying on one single incident or one person’s opinion. This “triangulation” involves collecting evidence from multiple sources to inform decisions[29]. For example, to assess professionalism, the PA might consider: attendance records, feedback from a staff nurse, and the student’s adherence to uniform policy and

For clinical skills, the PA could look at: direct observation (by themselves or a supervisor’s report), the student’s written reflection on that skill, and maybe a quiz or questions they answered on the underpinning knowledge. By gathering at least three points of evidence for each proficiency (where possible), the assessor can be confident in the reliability of the assessment. It also protects the integrity of the process – if a student disputes a decision, the PA can demonstrate it was based on well-rounded evidence, not personal bias. The SSSA explicitly states that practice assessors’ decisions should be informed by feedback from practice supervisors[29] and others, and that they should make objective, evidence-based judgments[58][60]. One practical tip is for Practice Assessors to keep a brief “assessment notes” diary during the placement: jot down any significant observations or feedback excerpts with dates. Then use these notes during the final interview to ensure all achievements and concerns are considered. In summary, effective supervision of student nurses is a team effort grounded in clear communication, ongoing support, and rigorous but fair assessment practices. Practice Supervisors and Assessors must work hand-in-hand (with input from Academic Assessors and others) to create an environment where students can thrive, and where any issues are promptly addressed. By following the guidance above – aligning with NMC standards – we help ensure that students become competent, confident professionals, and that patient safety and care quality are maintained throughout the learning process.
Utilising Spoke Opportunities
A spoke placement is a short-duration learning experience in an area related to or different from the student’s main (hub) placement. Spoke opportunities are invaluable for broadening a student’s exposure, allowing them to develop skills and insights that the current placement might not offer. They also foster inter-agency and inter-professional awareness, as students often engage with services outside the immediate clinical team. Here’s how to effectively utilize spoke placements:

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: What is a Spoke? In simple terms, a spoke placement is like a “field trip” or mini- placement. It can range from a few hours observing a specialist, to a couple of days or a week embedded in another team. The idea is that the student leaves their main placement temporarily to experience another setting that offers learning relevant to their proficiencies. Spokes are typically arranged when a particular proficiency is difficult to achieve in the current placement’s context[25]. For example, an adult nursing student on a general medical ward might arrange a spoke day in the wound care clinic to observe complex dressings, or with the diabetes specialist nurse to learn about insulin pump management, if those opportunities are rare on the ward.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Arranging Spoke Placements: Usually, the student should discuss potential spokes with their Practice Assessor or Supervisor early in the placement. Together, they identify learning needs that the main placement might not meet fully. The student (with support as needed) can then reach out to relevant departments or use established contacts (often via the Practice Education Facilitator or link tutor) to set up the spoke. It’s important to ensure the spoke area is expecting the student and that a supervisor there is identified to orient and supervise the student during the visit. The main placement’s management must also approve (so they know why the student is absent on those days). Many universities and trusts have guidelines for spokes – some require a short agreement form to be filled, noting the date, location, and objectives of the spoke. The student should be proactive but also realistic: a spoke should have a clear purpose, not just be time away.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Examples of Spoke Opportunities for Adult Nursing: Adult field students have a wide array of possibilities, such as: - Clinical Specialist Teams: e.g., a tissue viability nurse (wound/frailty team) to see advanced wound therapies, a stoma care nurse, a heart failure specialist nurse, or a falls prevention clinic. These experiences can enhance skills like assessment and care planning for specific conditions (like chronic wounds or fall risks). - Outpatient or Community Clinics: e.g., a wound clinic (as mentioned), dialysis unit, oncology day unit, or a GP surgery clinic (to see primary care management of adult conditions). A day in a chemotherapy suite could teach about patient education and monitoring during infusions; a day with district nurses could show holistic assessment in patients’ homes. - Allied Health Professional (AHP) Spokes: spending time with physiotherapists, occupational therapists, or dietitians. For instance, attending a frailty multidisciplinary team meeting or shadowing a physio in a rehab gym can help meet proficiencies around mobility, rehabilitation, and multi-agency working[67]. - Social Care or Third-Sector Services: e.g., an adult student might visit a

This builds awareness of how different organisations contribute to a patient’s wellbeing beyond the hospital. - Diverse Population Health Needs: e.g., a spoke with a Learning Disability liaison nurse to see how care is adapted for adults with learning disabilities, or with a Mental Health liaison team in the hospital (for an adult student to gain insight into mental health crises management in A&E or wards). For instance, a proficiency about “working in partnership to ensure safe discharge across services” could be well evidenced by a student spending time with a discharge coordinator or attending a community follow-up visit[68][69].

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Documenting and Assessing Spokes: When a student goes on a spoke, they should have specific objectives (ideally linked to proficiencies). They should inform their Practice Assessor what they intend to achieve. During the spoke, a supervising professional in that area can provide evidence – often a short written feedback or signing a section in the PAD that the student observed/participated in X and demonstrated Y. For example, in a spoke to a falls clinic, the physiotherapist might write, “Student attended falls assessment clinic; actively participated in assessing two patients, identified risk factors in environment and medications, and discussed care plans – showed good communication with older patients.” This evidence can then be used by the Practice Assessor to sign off relevant proficiencies (like risk assessment, multi-agency working, health promotion for falls prevention). The student should also reflect on the spoke experience in their portfolio or PAD, noting what they learned and linking it to their proficiencies.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Benefits of Spoke Placements: Spokes are beneficial in multiple ways: - They allow students to meet learning outcomes that might otherwise be unmet in their main placement, thus ensuring a well-rounded competence. “Spoke placements can be useful if there is limited exposure to a proficiency in a specific field of nursing”[70] – this flexibility helps students in all fields meet the universal standards. - They enhance understanding of the patient journey. For example, an adult ward student who visits a community mental health team gains appreciation for what happens after discharge for a patient with dual physical and mental health needs. - They promote inter-professional learning. Working with other professionals or teams on a spoke helps break silos. Students learn the roles of others, which fosters better teamwork. For instance, an adult nursing student who spends time with an occupational therapist will better understand how to plan safe discharges (like home adaptations needed), improving their collaboration back on the ward. - They encourage initiative and self-directed learning. Arranging and completing a spoke requires the student to be proactive, which is a professional

Arranging and completing a spoke requires the student to be proactive, which is a professional behavior in itself. - From a service perspective, spoke students can sometimes bring fresh enthusiasm to teams and strengthen relationships between hospital and community services or across departments.

Inter-agency Awareness: Through spokes, students often interact with external agencies – such as social workers, community matrons, or charity support workers. This builds awareness of the wider health and social care network. It’s important that nurses know how to signpost patients to these services (like referring to a social prescribing service for loneliness, or contacting a cultural liaison/diversity team for specific patient needs). A student might do a spoke with a hospital palliative care team and learn how they coordinate with hospice services; or visit a housing support organization to see social determinants of health firsthand. All these experiences contribute to a nurse who can work effectively across organisational boundaries – a key aspect of modern healthcare.
In conclusion, spoke placements are a strategic tool to enrich practice learning. Students should be encouraged and supported to utilize spokes thoughtfully, targeting them to their learning needs. Practice Assessors and Supervisors play a role in facilitating this (through flexibility in scheduling and using their networks to help set up experiences). By leveraging

spokes, a student can demonstrate creativity and commitment in meeting their proficiencies – and ultimately become a more versatile and knowledgeable practitioner. Always remember to bring the learning back to the main placement: after a spoke, students should share with their supervisors what they learned, possibly even presenting to the team if appropriate, thereby benefitting others and reinforcing their own learning.
Myth Busters
There are many misconceptions (“myths”) about practice learning and assessment. This section addresses common myths and provides factual clarification, helping students and supervisors focus on what is truly required. Below are several myth vs. fact pairings to clear up confusion:

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Myth: “Students must demonstrate every procedure and proficiency in an actual clinical setting – simulation doesn’t count.” Fact: Simulation does count as a legitimate way to learn and be assessed. The NMC explicitly supports the use of simulated practice learning to complement clinical placements[22]. Students are not expected to have a real patient for every single skill (especially if circumstances don’t allow); many skills can be safely learned and assessed in simulation labs or through drills. For instance, if a ward never has pediatric patients, an adult field student can still demonstrate pediatric BLS or airway management on a child manikin in a sim session. Assessors can sign off proficiencies based on simulation as long as a registered practitioner has overseen the student’s performance and is satisfied it meets the standard[24]. In fact, simulation is invaluable for high-risk but low-occurrence scenarios (cardiac arrest, severe anaphylaxis, etc.) – it ensures students get exposure and practice in those areas. The bottom line: Simulation is recognized and encouraged by the NMC as a means to achieve proficiencies, not a lesser alternative. Of course, if a real clinical

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: exposure and practice in those areas. The bottom line: Simulation is recognized and encouraged by the NMC as a means to achieve proficiencies, not a lesser alternative. Of course, if a real clinical opportunity arises, that’s great, but a well-run simulation can provide equally robust evidence of competence (plus the opportunity to repeat and refine skills).

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Myth: “Only my Practice Assessor’s observations can be used as evidence; feedback from other staff or patients doesn’t matter.” Fact: All relevant feedback and observations can contribute to the assessment decision. In the modern model, assessment is a collaborative effort. Practice Assessors are expected to seek and consider input from Practice Supervisors and others who work with the student[71][29]. So, if a senior healthcare assistant or a physiotherapist or a patient has given feedback about the student’s performance, that is valid evidence. For example, a patient’s compliment about how well a student provided education on their condition can support the proficiency on health promotion communication. Similarly, if three different nurses report that the student handles infection control excellently, the Practice Assessor should weigh that heavily. The myth likely stems from older models where only “sign-off mentors” mattered – but now practice supervision is a team activity. A Practice Assessor

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: makes the final call, but that call should be based on triangulated evidence (multiple sources) not just their own direct witnessing[29]. Additionally, a Practice Supervisor who directly observes a skill can sign in the PAD or give a statement for the PA to use. So students should engage with the whole team and gather feedback proactively. It’s also acceptable for skills to be initially signed by supervisors (if the PAD allows) and then the PA verifies them. The fact is: evidence of proficiency can include written testimonies from other professionals, skills lab assessments, patient feedback forms, reflective accounts, and more – not just the PA’s personal observation. Using a breadth of evidence leads to a fairer and more comprehensive assessment.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Myth: “Every example action in the toolkit (or PAD) must be completed for the proficiency to be achieved.” Fact: Not at all – the example actions are illustrative suggestions, not a mandatory checklist[4]. This toolkit and most PAD documents list several possible ways or sub-tasks by which a proficiency might be demonstrated. These are meant to guide and inspire, not to be ticked off one by one. A student can meet the proficiency through one or two well-evidenced actions; they do not need to do all the things on the list. For instance, if the proficiency is “Nutrition and hydration: contributes to planning, delivering and monitoring,” example actions might include assessing BMI, educating a patient about diet, and documenting fluid balance. The student might end up doing a thorough nutritional assessment and setting up a feeding plan for one patient – if that clearly demonstrates competence, that’s sufficient even if they didn’t, say, attend a dietician meeting (another example that might have been listed). The NMC’s stance is outcome-focused, meaning it’s about whether the student can achieve the outcome, not whether they tick off tasks[22]. In fact, overly focusing on ticking

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: might have been listed). The NMC’s stance is outcome-focused, meaning it’s about whether the student can achieve the outcome, not whether they tick off tasks[22]. In fact, overly focusing on ticking checklists can detract from holistic learning. Practice Assessors should use professional judgment: one student may evidence a proficiency differently than another, and that’s fine. Quality of performance matters more than quantity of tasks. The toolkit’s repeated reminder is that examples are not exhaustive nor compulsory – they’re “suggestive actions, not limited to” the list given[72][73]. So, use them as a menu of options and ideas, and feel free to substitute alternatives that achieve the same end.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Myth: “Any RN can’t be a supervisor or assessor unless they’ve done a specific mentorship course.” Fact: Under current NMC standards, any registered nurse (or midwife/NA) can supervise students as part of their role, provided they are prepared and supported by their employer[5][50]. The old “mentor” qualification is no longer a regulatory requirement. Practice Assessors should be registered nurses with suitable experience in the student’s field, and while many will have mentorship training or similar, it’s not mandated by the NMC now – it’s up to employers to ensure assessors are prepared. So, a ward staff nurse who hasn’t been on a mentorship course can still supervise a student (and in fact is expected to, as part of collective

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: responsibility). They would not, however, be the Practice Assessor unless designated as such; PAs often are more senior or experienced staff who have had some preparation. But even that is flexible – a competent Band 5 RN could be a PA if supported. The myth sometimes causes staff to shy away from working with students – but in truth, every registered nurse has a role in student education, guided by the Code to support the next generation (section on promoting professionalism and trust). Another angle: some think only nurses can supervise – but actually other registered professionals can too, for relevant learning experiences (e.g., a student could be supervised by an occupational therapist during a mobility session)[74][75]. The key is that these supervisors communicate with the nurse team. In summary, while most organizations still offer mentorship or supervisor training (which is good practice), lack of a formal “mentor” title does not exclude a nurse from supervising or even assessing within the SSSA framework. What’s important is that assessors are allocated and supported, and all supervisors know how to give feedback and guidance.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Myth: “Proficiencies can only be signed off if directly observed in person by the assessor.” Fact: Proficiencies should be demonstrated, but the demonstration can be to any suitable registrant who can then inform the assessment. The Practice Assessor does not need to personally witness everything. If a competency was observed by a Practice Supervisor (or multiple supervisors) consistently, the PA can accept their documented observations as evidence[71]. For instance, a night-shift supervisor might observe the student handling an emergency and later relay that to the PA, who wasn’t present – the PA can then discuss it with the student and use it as evidence of, say, managing care under pressure. The PA might ask the supervisor to write a short note in the PAD or email for the record. Additionally, certain proficiencies might be demonstrated via simulation or discussion with the PA rather than live clinical action – that’s still valid. The NMC encourages assessors to gather a range of evidence (direct and indirect)[29]. Of course, where possible, direct observation is great. But in reality, given shift patterns and breadth of skills, a PA will often rely on records and feedback from

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: (direct and indirect)[29]. Of course, where possible, direct observation is great. But in reality, given shift patterns and breadth of skills, a PA will often rely on records and feedback from others. This is perfectly acceptable. It prevents the student from being penalized just because the “right” person didn’t see them do something. A well-rounded assessment might include: direct observation by PA for some things, observation by others for some, scenario discussions for others – collectively building the case. So, the fact is that assessment is a team sport and not limited to the PA’s own sight. As long as the evidence is documented and trusted, the PA can use it. (The one exception: any summative exams or specific sign-off tools might require presence, but those are separate from ongoing proficiencies.)

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
These myth busters should reassure students and practice staff and correct any erroneous practices. By dispelling myths, we ensure everyone approaches the practice learning process with accurate information and less anxiety. Remember, when in doubt, refer back
to NMC standards or ask an Academic Assessor for clarification – often the answer will be that there is more flexibility and support than the myth suggests.
Proficiency Clustering
In real nursing care, skills and competencies do not happen in isolation – a single patient care scenario will often involve multiple proficiencies at once. “Proficiency clustering” refers to recognizing that one learning event or assessment opportunity can provide evidence for several proficiencies simultaneously. This approach encourages holistic learning and reduces the need to artificially compartmentalize skills. It also mirrors true nursing practice, where you integrate various skills seamlessly to care for a patient.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Concept: Proficiencies are listed individually in the standards and PAD, but they are not stand-alone tasks. The NMC acknowledges that a nurse’s actions usually demonstrate a combination of knowledge and skills[76]. For example, consider something as routine as a medication round: the student isn’t just “administering medicine” (procedure) – they are also communicating with the patient (communication proficiency), performing an assessment (checking patient identity, allergies, understanding), applying pharmacology knowledge (knowledge proficiency), and documenting (record-keeping proficiency). If we artificially split those, we’d miss the bigger picture that the student can coordinate all those aspects in one go.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Assessment in Clusters: Practice Assessors and Supervisors should consider, when planning an assessment, how one situation can tick off multiple proficiencies. This is efficient and realistic. For instance, a student leading a patient discharge planning meeting could be evidencing communication skills, collaborative working, teaching the patient about medications, understanding of referrals, and documentation – all in that one activity[68][77]. Instead of needing five separate sign-offs, the assessor might observe that discharge process and then sign off five related proficiencies at once, with appropriate commentary.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Example – Nursing Discharge (Year 2): As given in the toolkit, a part 2 student taking part in a discharge of a complex patient demonstrates a range of proficiencies. During that discharge process, the student will support the patient in making informed choices (Proficiency P1)[78], apply principles of partnership working and respect capacity (P2)[79], provide clear explanations about the patient’s treatment and follow-up (P5, P22)[80][81], ensure documentation like the discharge letter and care plan is accurate (P7)[82], and coordinate with other services for continuity of care (P31)[83]. In doing so, they might also demonstrate leadership and confidence appropriate to a Year 2 level. Instead of viewing P1, P2, P5, P7, P22, P31 as separate unrelated checkboxes, the assessor clusters them around the “discharge” event. If the student performed well, evidence from that event (like the supervisor’s observation notes, the completed referral form they filled, feedback from the patient or social worker present) can satisfy all those proficiencies. This not only saves time but reinforces to the student how these skills interlink in practice.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Example – Wound Care (Year 3): Imagine a Year 3 student managing a patient with a complex surgical wound. In one afternoon, the student assesses the wound (showing proficiency in assessment and decision-making), performs a dressing change with sterile technique (showing procedural skill and infection control), educates the patient on wound care at home (health promotion and communication), and documents the wound progress (record-keeping). This single scenario can provide evidence for proficiencies in assessment, infection prevention, patient education, pain management, and documentation. The assessor could cluster these under “Managed complex wound care for Patient X” and sign off multiple items such as: "Demonstrates person-centred assessment and monitoring of wound healing," "Performs wound dressing using aseptic technique," "Provides effective education to patient and carer," "Evaluates and documents care outcomes." Each is a distinct proficiency, but all were met together.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Example – Breaking Bad News (Communication & Emotional Support): If a student is involved in (or simulates) a scenario of breaking bad news or discussing end-of-life care with a patient and family, it’s an opportunity to cluster proficiencies related to communication, ethical practice, and interprofessional support. In that one conversation, the student might demonstrate empathy, ability to adjust communication to the situation, understanding of safeguarding or supporting vulnerable people, and working alongside perhaps a doctor or specialist nurse. A single observed “difficult conversation” could thus address: communication skills, respecting dignity, recognizing one’s role in the team (knowing when to get senior help), and emotional support measures. Instead of seeing those as separate, the assessor can write up a holistic account. This aligns with practice because breaking bad news is not a single skill – it’s a combination of knowledge, attitude, communication technique, and teamwork.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Encouraging Students to Think Holistically: Students can also be coached to identify clusters. At the start of a placement, a useful exercise is to pick a common procedure or activity and map out which proficiencies might be evidenced through it. For example, “Mr. A’s morning care” – that could hit on communication (talking to him during personal care), infection control (washing hands, PPE), fundamental care (bathing, skin inspection), assessment (noticing a pressure sore risk, or checking vital signs), and documentation (charting intake/output, etc.). By seeing this, students realize they don’t need a separate event for each line in the PAD; they need to maximize each event. This not only reduces their anxiety about “so many things to do” but also reflects how they will actually practice as nurses – integrating tasks efficiently.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
Documentation of Clustered Evidence: When writing in the PAD or assessment forms, Practice Assessors should reference the cluster scenario and list which proficiencies it covered. For instance: “Observed student lead a MDT discharge planning meeting for patient with stroke (14/11/25). During this, student demonstrated: P2 – partnership and shared decision making (involved patient and OT in plans); P5 – provided clear information about medications and used teach-back; P7 – documentation in discharge plan was thorough and e-mailed to community team; P31 – coordinated with social worker for safe transition. All achieved to the level required.” This single narrative ties them together.
Similarly, any reflections the student writes can be more holistic (“Reflecting on coordinating that discharge, I realized I used many skills: communication, teamwork, clinical knowledge about stroke, etc.”).

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Benefits of Clustering: It prevents the fragmentation of nursing care into artificial bits. It reinforces to the student how knowledge, skills, and attitudes come together. It also prevents over-assessing the student – if one situation suffices, there’s no need to set up five separate assessments which can lead to assessment fatigue and redundant paperwork. Clustering is also protective in terms of validity: it shows the student can bring everything together in context, which is ultimately what matters for safe practice. A student might tick off a skill in isolation (like calculating a drug dose on paper, or doing a manual handling move in a class), but the true test is doing it amidst real care. Clustering captures that.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Using Clustering for Complex Care: In higher parts (Year 3), patients often have complex needs – multiple conditions or social factors. A scenario like coordinating a complex discharge or managing a deteriorating patient will inherently cover multiple proficiencies (from acute care skills to leadership). For example, a student managing a patient who suddenly becomes hypoxic will use assessment skills (recognize signs), communication (call the doctor, SBAR), technical skills (maybe administer oxygen, do an ECG), and teamwork (allocate someone to reassure family, someone to fetch emergency trolley). If they do this in simulation or real life, an assessor can cluster acute care proficiencies (like “recognize and respond to deterioration,” “effective communication under pressure,” “team leadership in emergency,” and “infection control during emergency interventions”). This paints a richer picture of the student’s readiness for registration than ticking each independently at different times.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
In essence, proficiency clustering is about seeing the forest rather than just the trees. It encourages a focus on integrated practice. When planning assessments or writing up evidence, think in terms of patient stories or nursing scenarios and identify the constellation of competencies within them. As one nursing educator aptly said, “Nursing is not a checklist; it’s a tapestry of skills woven together.” Clustering helps us evaluate how well students can weave that tapestry. By using this approach, we also prepare students to think comprehensively – to always consider the whole patient and situation, rather than performing tasks in isolation. This ultimately leads to better, safer care and nurses who are reflective and versatile in their practice.
(For additional guidance, the NMC’s standards framework encourages integrative assessment approaches and many AEIs provide examples of how multiple outcomes can be met in a single assessment – leveraging that can simplify the journey for both student and assessor.)

Glossary of Terms
Throughout this toolkit (and more broadly in nursing education), certain terms and acronyms are used which may be unfamiliar. Below is a glossary of key terms and abbreviations, particularly those related to supervision, assessment, and professional practice:
Practice Supervisor (PS): A registered nurse, midwife or nursing associate (or other registered health professional) who supervises and supports nursing students on a day-to-day basis in the practice setting. They act as role models and facilitate learning, providing feedback on the student’s progress[95][50]. All qualified nurses are expected to act as supervisors when working with students, helping them to learn while ensuring safe patient care.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
Practice Assessor (PA): A registered nurse who is responsible for assessing a nursing student’s achievement of proficiencies and outcomes in practice for a specific part of the programme[56]. The PA makes the final decision on whether proficiencies are met, informed by feedback from Practice Supervisors[49][96]. Each student is assigned a PA (per placement or per year) who conducts formal assessment meetings and works in partnership with the Academic Assessor to evaluate progress.
Academic Assessor (AA): A registered nurse in the academic setting (typically a lecturer) who collates and confirms the student’s achievement of proficiencies and academic outcomes for each part of the programme[38]. The AA collaborates with the Practice Assessor to make decisions about progression[48]. A different AA is usually assigned in each year, to maintain objectivity. They ensure theoretical learning and practice performance are both considered.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
Approved Education Institution (AEI): An NMC-approved education provider, usually a university or college, that runs nursing programmes. AEIs are accountable for meeting NMC education standards and work in partnership with practice learning organizations to deliver the curriculum[97]. (Sometimes still called “HEI” – Higher Education Institution – but AEI is the term used when NMC approval is in context.)
Practice Learning Partners: Organisations that provide placement opportunities for students – e.g., NHS Trusts, GP practices, community services, independent hospitals. They partner with AEIs to support students in meeting proficiencies[98]. These partners must also meet NMC standards (like having appropriate support and governance for student learning).
Practice Assessment Document (PAD): The official document (physical or electronic, e.g., OnlinePARE) where students’ practice proficiency outcomes are recorded by supervisors/assessors. It usually includes competency checklists,

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
feedback sections, reflective logs, and interview records. Accurate completion of the PAD is required for progression[62]. (MORA is a variant used for midwifery; some regions have different names, but PAD is generic here.)
MORA: Stands for Midwifery Ongoing Record of Achievement. Mentioned here for completeness – midwifery equivalent to PAD, but sometimes nursing uses the term in certain regions if they adopted a similar approach. In an adult nursing context, you’ll mostly hear PAD, but if you see MORA, it’s analogous.
Formative Assessment: Assessments or feedback opportunities that are developmental and do not count as pass/fail of the placement. Formative learning allows the student to receive input on how to improve without it affecting progression[99]. For example, a midway interview or an early medication round observation might be formative – highlighting areas to work on before the final (summative) assessment.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
Summative Assessment: The formal evaluation at the end of a period which determines if outcomes are achieved (and does count towards progression)[100]. In practice, the final interview where the Practice Assessor signs off competencies is summative – its result (achieved/not achieved) will decide if the student passes that part. Summative = “for the record” assessment.
Retrieval (Re-assessment): If a student fails to achieve certain outcomes by the end of a placement or part, a retrieval period is an opportunity to redo or complete those outcomes. Often a short additional placement or extended time (e.g., 4 weeks maximum) is given for the student to meet the requirements[101]. The AA and PA plan this, and it’s a second chance without having to repeat the entire year, as long as the student succeeds in the retrieval. Commonly invoked if a student narrowly misses a couple of proficiencies or had extenuating circumstances.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
Simulation (Simulated Learning): An artificial or staged clinical scenario used for education. Simulation may involve mannequins, role-play, virtual reality, or task trainers. It allows students to practice skills and decision-making in a safe environment[23]. In this toolkit, simulation is also considered an assessment method for certain proficiencies. Good simulation includes briefing and debriefing sessions. High-fidelity sims might simulate an entire patient journey; low-fidelity might be simple skill practice.
Spoke Placement: A short-duration placement or visit to a clinical area outside of the main (hub) placement. Used to gain experience or skills not available on the hub. For example, during a hospital placement (hub), a day spent with a community nurse team might be a spoke. Spokes help ensure exposure to all necessary proficiencies[25][102]. Sometimes also called “alternative” or “supplementary” placement.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
PSRBs (Professional, Statutory and Regulatory Bodies): This term refers to organizations like the NMC (regulatory) or others that oversee professional education and standards. In a university context, PSRB requirements are those set by bodies such as the NMC that the programme must adhere to. For students, just know NMC is the key PSRB for nursing – it sets the standards and approves programmes.
Reasonable Adjustments: Modifications or accommodations made to support students (or staff or patients) with disabilities or specific needs, to give them equal opportunities. In education, this could mean allowing a dyslexic student to use coloured overlays in documentation or giving extra time to complete written work, or providing assistive technology. In practice, could be adjusting shift patterns for a health reason, or ensuring a wheelchair-accessible environment for a student with mobility issues. These adjustments are required by law (Equality Act 2010 in the UK) so that no student is disadvantaged unfairly. They must be “reasonable” – i.e., not compromising safety or standards, but as far as possible enabling full participation.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: Good Health and Good Character: An NMC requirement that those admitted to and who complete nursing programmes (and apply for registration) are in good health and of good character. Good health doesn’t mean absence of any illness; it means that someone’s health condition is well-managed such that they can practise safely (with or without adjustments). Good character means having integrity, honesty, and trustworthiness – essentially being suited to the responsibility of professional practice. Universities assess these at admission (via occupational health, references, DBS checks for criminal record) and throughout (if there are concerns like dishonesty or unprofessional behaviour, it can trigger “fitness to practise” processes). It’s why students must disclose issues and uphold professional behaviour even as students – because they’re being judged on character continuously. On qualifying, the AEI confirms the student’s good health and character to the NMC.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
Co-production: In the context of education and healthcare, co-production means involving all stakeholders – including service users (patients), carers, students, and front-line staff – in the design, development, and review of services or educational programmes. For example, this toolkit might be a result of co-production if student representatives and patients contributed to its content. Co-production ensures multiple perspectives are considered, often leading to more user-friendly and effective outcomes. In practice learning, co-production could mean students and supervisors working together to plan learning activities that benefit patients as well (like a student project to improve patient information leaflets done with patient input).
PEF (Practice Education Facilitator) / Practice Educator: These are roles (often experienced nurses) that exist in many NHS trusts to support student placements. A PEF might help coordinate placement capacity, support supervisors and

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
assessors with training, and provide pastoral or learning support to students. They are a link between the AEI and the practice environment. If a student is struggling or an assessor is unsure about an assessment process, the PEF can be called upon. (Titles vary: some places call them Clinical Placement Facilitators, etc., but PEF is common.)[103] indicates how PEFs act as intermediaries and ensure processes are followed for additional support if needed.
Nominated Person (for practice setting): The SSSA requires each practice area to have a designated person responsible for coordinating student support – this could be a ward manager or a PEF or an education link nurse. Their role is to be a clear point of contact for any student issues and ensure the environment supports learning[104]. Students should be told who this person is (e.g., “Sister X is our student link – speak to her if you have any concerns or need help beyond your mentor”). This person often liaises with the AEI if something needs escalating.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
Learning Environment: Not just the physical space, but the overall context in which learning occurs – including the team culture, values, and opportunities available[105]. A positive learning environment is welcoming, encourages questions, and treats students as learners (not just extra hands). The NMC standards emphasize that a quality learning environment is vital for effective student development.
SSSA: Acronym for Standards for Student Supervision and Assessment (mentioned above). Often used when discussing the new framework (post-2019) for how students are supported in practice.
The Code: Short for the NMC Code of Professional Standards of Practice and Behaviour for Nurses, Midwives and Nursing Associates (2018). Usually just called “the Code.” It’s the fundamental guide for conduct and ethics in nursing. Phrases like “in line with the Code” often appear in assessment documents, reminding that behavior and actions must adhere to those principles (e.g., maintaining confidentiality, obtaining consent, etc.). The four themes of the Code – Prioritise People, Practise Effectively, Preserve Safety, Promote Professionalism and Trust – underpin any discussion of professionalism.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
This glossary is not exhaustive but covers terms frequently encountered in the context of this toolkit and clinical practice education. Students should familiarize themselves with these terms. If unsure about any terminology in practice, don’t hesitate to ask a supervisor or academic – understanding the language of practice education is part of becoming a professional. As one learns these concepts, they often become second nature. Knowing them will also help in job interviews and early career, as these concepts (like understanding SSSA roles or the importance of reasonable adjustments) will remain relevant as you transition from student to registered nurse.
Useful Resources
There are numerous resources and references available to support practice learning and assessment. Below is a list of key documents, websites, and platforms, along with a brief explanation of each. These are valuable for students and practice staff alike, for further reading, guidance, or e-learning opportunities:

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
NMC Standards of Proficiency for Registered Nurses (2018): The core NMC document listing the competencies (proficiencies) and Annex skills that every nurse must achieve by registration. This is essentially the “curriculum” of what you need to be able to do. It’s available on the NMC website[106][107]. Students can refer to it to understand the full scope of skills (e.g., it details in Annex B the procedures you must master). Practice educators might use it to ensure their teaching covers required elements.
NMC Annexe A & B Skills Listings: Appendices to the above standards, specifically listing communication skills (Annexe A) and nursing procedures (Annexe B) new nurses must demonstrate. For quick reference to what’s included (like which invasive procedures, which communication techniques), these lists are invaluable. Often incorporated into PADs, but the standalone lists can be found on NMC’s site. Annexe B essentially is the “clinical skills checklist” for qualifying nurses[33]. We mention it separately because it’s frequently referenced in practice (“Is that an Annexe B skill we need to cover?”).

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
NMC Standards for Student Supervision and Assessment (SSSA, 2018): The guidance outlining how students are to be supervised and assessed in practice, including the roles of PS, PA, and AA as discussed[29]. Available on NMC’s website, it provides the formal rules (e.g., one PA cannot be also the PS, there should be scheduled communication between PA and AA[65], etc.). Useful for practice staff to ensure compliance and for students to know what support to expect.
The Code (NMC, 2018): The professional code of conduct for nurses, midwives, and nursing associates. It’s a short but powerful document structured in four themes (Prioritise people, Practise effectively, Preserve safety, Promote professionalism and trust). Available online as PDF[108] and via NMC app. This underpins all practice – students should use it as a reference for any ethical or professional dilemmas. For example, if unsure about confidentiality or consent, the Code has direct instructions. Citing the Code in reflections or discussions shows understanding of professional values.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
NMC Standards Framework for Nursing and Midwifery Education (2018): A document aimed at education providers and practice partners outlining quality standards for programme delivery (learning culture, student support, faculty qualifications, etc.). While mainly institution-focused, it’s the reason behind many policies that affect students (like having a safe environment, raising concerns
protocols, inclusive practice). Educators might reference it when making local policy. It’s available on NMC site if one wants to understand the principles behind how programmes are managed.
“Standards for student supervision and assessment: A brief guide” (NMC or AEI resource): Many universities or the NMC have produced summary guides or flowcharts of the new supervision/assessment model. These can be handy quick references for who does what (PS vs PA vs AA). For example, a one-page PDF that says “Practice Supervisor: ANY registered staff… Practice Assessor: assigned, conducts assessment… etc.” If available, it’s great for clinical areas to pin on noticeboards. (One such resource is often found under NMC’s Supporting information on their site).

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
Health Education England (HEE) – Learning Resources: HEE provides many resources for clinical learning. Two notable ones:
HEE e-Learning for Healthcare (e-LfH): An online platform with free modules on a huge range of topics, from clinical skills (like venepuncture, ECG interpretation, catheter care, dementia training) to broader topics (like safeguarding, mental health awareness). Throughout this toolkit, various proficiencies list “Online Learning (e- LfH)” – those refer to specific modules on this platform. Students can register with their NHS email or through their university and access interactive courses. It’s a great way to supplement practice learning with theory and is often required in PAD action plans. For example, there are e-LfH modules on blood transfusion safety or on using early warning scores. Link: www.e-lfh.org.uk (search for the needed topic). We highly recommend students utilize these, as they’re aligned with national frameworks and sometimes even give certificates for portfolios.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
HEE NHS Learning Hub: A repository for sharing learning materials and best practices. Some regions upload case studies or videos here. It’s a newer platform where one might find scenario-based learning packages or simulation scripts shared by others.
OnlinePARE (Practice Assessment Record & Evaluation): An online system used by some universities/regions to host the PAD and associated assessments. If your programme uses OnlinePARE (or a similar system like PebblePad or ARC), it is the platform where supervisors and assessors log in to fill forms (initial, midway, final interviews, skill sign-offs, etc.)[109]. OnlinePARE also often facilitates submitting placement evaluations (feedback from students about the placement). Knowing how to navigate and use this system is crucial – if you’re not sure, ask for a tutorial early in placement. The system often has guides available on the login page or a help section. While it might seem just a tech thing, it’s actually central to documenting your progress. A tip: ensure notifications from it go to your email so you don’t miss when your PA signs something or requests you fill in your parts.

instruction: What are the NMC standards for safe administration of medicines?
output: Local Trust Policies and Guidelines: Each placement area will have local policies (for example, on medication administration, infection control, moving & handling, etc.). These are resources too – students should be oriented to where to find them (intranet or policy folders). For instance, if trying to meet a proficiency on medicines management, referencing the local IV policy or Medicines Code is useful evidence that you’ve engaged with required knowledge. Many trusts have online policy libraries accessible via any trust computer.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: RCN (Royal College of Nursing) and RCM (Royal College of Midwives) Resources: The RCN offers a range of guidance documents, competencies, and learning materials on its website for members (and some for non-members). For adult nursing, RCN has guides on accountability, delegation, record-keeping, and clinical topics like catheter care or wound care. They’re not regulatory but are respected best-practice guidelines. If a student is interested in a deeper dive into, say, wound management, the RCN’s wound care pages or best practice statements could be beneficial. RCM similarly for midwifery (less relevant for adult field except as a concept). There’s also RCNi Learning (e-learning from RCN’s publishing arm) which some universities subscribe to, offering interactive case studies.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: NHS Constitution and Values Materials: These outline the principles of the NHS and the rights of patients and staff. Many trusts include NHS values in their induction and expect students to know them (Respect and dignity, Compassion, etc.). Resources include the NHS Constitution document and associated e-learning or videos on patient experience. It’s not a “must cite” in proficiencies, but understanding it will enrich a student’s practice and show commitment to NHS ethos.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output: HEE “Quality Framework” and “Education Contract”: These are more for the system level, but since they were mentioned in the user-files index: the NHS Education Contract (in England) is an agreement that outlines the expectations of trusts providing placements (like ensuring mentorship, etc.) and what funding they get in return (often called the “Tariff”). The HEE Quality Framework sets standards for quality in education and training, including clinical learning environments[110]. These documents assure that if you’re a student, the placement should meet certain criteria (like having a safe environment, induction provided, supervision available). They aren’t something a student uses day-to-day, but it’s reassuring that these frameworks exist – if a placement is substandard, these are what PEFs or universities might reference to demand improvements. They’re available on HEE’s website for those curious about the “bigger picture” of how your training is quality- controlled.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
Student Support Services (University and Trust): A reminder that resources also include people and services: personal tutors, student union advice, occupational health, mental health support, financial advice, etc. Many students overlook these, but they can be lifelines if you’re struggling. Also, within trusts, the education team,
library services (with access to journals, e-books), and practice development nurses are there to help your learning. So “resource” isn’t just online or paper – it’s human too.

instruction: Explain the NMC standards of proficiency for registered nurses.
output:
library services (with access to journals, e-books), and practice development nurses are there to help your learning. So “resource” isn’t just online or paper – it’s human too.
The above list is not exhaustive but covers major resources that an adult nursing student and their supervisors would find useful. Each item can provide additional learning or clarify standards. We recommend bookmarking the NMC standards on your device, enrolling in relevant e-LfH modules as you encounter those topics in practice, and making use of OnlinePARE (or equivalent) to track your progress. Knowledge of these resources also helps in job interviews or when transitioning to qualified nurse – showing that you know where to find information to keep your practice up-to-date (a trait of a self-directed professional). Lastly, don’t forget to complete placement evaluations on platforms like OnlinePARE or university surveys – these are resources for future improvements, and your feedback could help enhance the learning experience for the next cohort.
Part 1 (Year 1) – Guided Participation in Care

instruction: What are the first-year (Part One) nursing proficiencies according to the NMC standards?
output:
Part 1 (Year 1) – Guided Participation in Care Part One students engage in guided participation in care, performing with increasing confidence under close supervision. In Year 1, the focus is on fundamental nursing skills, communication, and developing a basic understanding of evidence-based practice. The student is expected to take a proactive role in care while requiring guidance and frequent feedback. Part 2 (Year 2) – Active Participation with Minimal Guidance
Part Two students engage in active participation in care with minimal guidance, performing with increased confidence and competence. In Year 2, the student transitions to greater independence: they are expected to care for a larger workload (e.g., a small patient group) under supervision, start performing more complex skills (some with an asterisk * can be achieved either in Year 2 or deferred to Year 3 if not encountered), and take more initiative in clinical decision-making. Part 3 (Year 3) – Practising Independently and Leading Care
Part Three students practise independently with minimal supervision, leading and coordinating care with confidence. In Year 3, the student should function close to the level of a newly qualified nurse, demonstrating leadership, management of complex care, and ability to integrate multiple proficiencies simultaneously. These often encapsulate multiple skills at once (proficiency clustering is common). By end of Part 3, all starred () skills from earlier parts should be accomplished. The student is expected to lead* more and require occasional guidance rather than continuous direction.

output:

Note: At the end of Part 3, the expectation is that the student can function safely and effectively as an entry-level registered nurse. They should be capable of managing full patient loads, performing all fundamental skills (and many advanced ones) independently (with support resources available as for any practitioner), making sound clinical decisions, and leading teams in routine care. The examples above depict a high level of initiative and critical thinking. Students will vary in confidence; the role of the Practice Assessor is to ensure by final sign-off that any remaining development needs are minor and will be addressed in preceptorship, not fundamental gaps in competence. The Part 3 student is essentially a team colleague – requiring minimal prompting – and the toolkit’s examples aim to prepare them for that role.
(Remind Part 3 students: always seek help in unfamiliar or high-risk situations; independence does not mean doing everything alone. True competence includes recognizing when to ask for input. This attitude ensures safe practice as they transition to qualified nurse.)

Reminder: The actions listed across all years are suggestive and not an exhaustive checklist. Every clinical setting is unique; students and supervisors will find alternative ways to evidence proficiencies. The key is to ensure that by the end of each part – and certainly by the end of Part 3 – the student can meet the NMC Standards of Proficiency in a holistic, integrated manner, ready for professional registration.
Closing Notes and Acknowledgements
This comprehensive toolkit, “Proficiencies for Adult Nursing,” was authored by Lincoln Gombedza with the aim of supporting students and practice staff in the challenging journey of nursing education. It is intended to be a living document – one that can be adapted by local education providers and practice partners to fit specific contexts or updated as standards evolve. Users are encouraged to take the framework provided here and make it their own: insert local policies, preferred resources, or area-specific competencies where relevant. The heart of the toolkit is to promote consistency in supporting students to achieve proficiency, while still allowing flexibility for individual learning needs and clinical environments.

Third Year Learning Disability/Mental Health -medicines Management:
This assessment must be completed by the end of Third Year where the student safely administers medicines to a group of patients/service users or a caseload of patients/service users in community settings.
During Third Year the student should be developing their knowledge, skills, and competencies in relation to the safe administration of medicines. This assessment should normally be undertaken with a small group of patients/service users or caseload.
The student must be allowed a number of practice opportunities to administer medicines under supervision prior to this assessment.
The student must work within the legal and ethical frameworks that underpin safe and effective medicines management and work within national and local policies.
